metadata.title: FORECASTING COVID-19 PANDEMIC: A DATA-DRIVEN ANALYSIS

abstract.text: In this paper, a new Susceptible-Exposed-Symptomatic Infectious-Asymptomatic Infectious-Quarantined-Hospitalized-Recovered-Dead (SEI D I U QHRD) deterministic compartmental model has been proposed and calibrated for describing the transmission dynamics of the novel coronavirus disease . A calibration process is executed through the solution of an inverse problem with the help of a Trust-Region-Reflective algorithm, used to determine the best parameter values that would fit the model response. The purpose of this study is to give a tentative prediction of the epidemic peak for Russia, Brazil, India and Bangladesh which could become the next COVID-19 hotspots in no time. Based on the publicly available epidemiological data from late January until 10 May, it has been estimated that the number of daily new symptomatic infectious cases for the above mentioned countries could reach the peak around the beginning of June with the peak size of ∼ 15, 774 symptomatic infectious cases in Russia, ∼ 26, 449 cases in Brazil, ∼ 9, 504 cases in India and ∼ 2, 209 cases in Bangladesh. Based on our analysis, the estimated value of the basic reproduction number (R 0 ) as of May 11, 2020 was found to be ∼ 4.234 in Russia, ∼ 5.347 in Brazil, ∼ 5.218 in India, ∼ 4.649 in the United Kingdom and ∼ 3.5 in Bangladesh. Moreover, with an aim to quantify the uncertainty of our model parameters, Latin hypercube sampling-partial rank correlation coefficient (LHS-PRCC) which is a global sensitivity analysis (GSA) method is applied which elucidates that, for Russia, the recovery rate of undetected asymptomatic carriers, the rate of getting home-quarantined or self-quarantined and the transition rate from quarantined class to susceptible class are the most influential parameters, whereas the rate of getting home-quarantined or self-quarantined and the inverse of the COVID-19 incubation period are highly sensitive parameters in Brazil, India, Bangladesh and the United Kingdom which could significantly affect the transmission dynamics of the novel coronavirus. Our analysis also suggests that relaxing social distancing restrictions too quickly could exacerbate the epidemic outbreak in the above mentioned countries.

The forward problem consists in providing initial conditions (IC) and a set of pa-203 rameters, represented by the pair α = (x 0 , p), and compute by means of numerical 204 integration the model response x(t) from which a scalar observable ψ(α, t) is ob-205 tained. In the forward problem, α represents all IC and system parameters from (1), 206 while ψ(α, t) is the new cases N w system response which can be calculated using daily 207 reported cumulative cases real-time data.

Since the map f has a polynomial nature in x, it is continuously differentiable 209 function in x. Thus, the existence and uniqueness theorem for ordinary differential 210 equations guarantees that the initial value problem of (3) has a unique solution. In In this work, the evaluation of the system response in the forward problem is solved 214 numerically by using Runge-kutta (4,5) method and the scalar observable of interest 215 N w is used to assess the simulation when compared with real data of the COVID- In formal terms, given an observation vector y ∈ F and a prediction vector ψ(α) ∈ F , the calibration aims at finding a vector of parameters α * such that

Numerical results on the recent COVID-19 data from Russia, Brazil, India, Bangladesh 500 and the UK have been analyzed. Based on the projection as of May 11, 2020, Russia 501 will reach the peak in terms of daily infected cases and death cases around end of May.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: Brazil and India will reach the peak in terms of daily infected cases and death cases 503 around beginning of June. Based on the projection the United Kingdom may have 504 a second wave of infection provided that lockdown is lifted. To end the pandemic, it 505 is mandatory to actively seek out potential spreaders, particularly the asymptomatic 506 spreaders which requires massive scale testing. Such a level of testing would effectively 507 bring the R 0 below 1 in the above mentioned countries which will eventually cause the 508 pandemic to fade out. 509 27 . BIBREF0.title: Modelling the epidemic trend of the 511 2019 novel coronavirus outbreak in China

FIGREF0.text: comparing model predictions with real-time data in order to evaluate if they of a small group of infected individuals to a large population. In this model we focus our 114 study on eight components of the epidemic flow, i.e. {S(t), E(t), I D (t), I U (t), Q(t), H(t), R(t), D(t)} 115 which indicate the number of the susceptible individuals, exposed individuals (infected 116 however not yet to be infectious, in an incubation period), symptomatic infectious 117 individuals (confirmed with infectious capacity), asymptomatic infectious individuals 118 (undetected but infectious), quarantined, hospitalized (under treatment), recovered 119 cases (immuned) and death cases (or closed cases). Then the entire number of popu-120 lation in a certain region or country is N = S + E + I D + I U + Q + H + R + D. The 121 following assumptions are considered in the formulation of the model: Emigration from the population and immigration into the population have not 123 been taken into account in model formulation as there is negligible proportion of 124 individuals move in and out of the population at a specific time frame.

In addition, 1/φ D , 1/φ U and 148 1/φ H represent the mean period of isolation for the detected symptomatic infectious in-149 dividuals, undetected asymptomatic carriers and hospitalized patients. FIGREF4.text: incubation period for COVID-19 is estimated to average 5.1 days Lauer et al., 154 (2020), similar to other model-based estimates Li et al., (2020), giving κ = 1/5.1 day −1 . 155 Some previous model-based estimates of infectious duration are on the order of several 156 days Li et al., (2020); Ferguson et al., (2020); Tang et al., (2020), with giving about 157 7 days for asymptomatic individuals to recover. However, the clinical course of the 158 disease is typically much longer: In a study of hospitalized patients Verity et al., 159 (2020), average total duration of illness until hospital discharge or death was 21 days, 160 and moreover, the median duration of viral shedding was 20 days in survivors. The 161 effective transmission rate (as a constant), β, ranges from around 0.2 − 1.5 day −1 in 162 prior modeling studies Shen et al. (2020); Read et al., (2020); Li et al., (2020), and 163 typically trends down with time Li et al., (2020); Tang et al., (2020

The above result implies that a small influx of infected individuals 197would not generate large outbreaks if R 0 < 1, and the disease will persist (be endemic)198    in the population if R 0 > 1.

FIGREF11.text: calibration problem seeks to find a set of parameters that, to a certain 221 degree, makes the model response as close as possible to the empirical observations 222 (reference data), once, due to the errors on model conception and reference data ac-223 quisition, it is (practically) impossible for the forward map to reproduce outbreak 224 observations. 225 The mathematical setting for this case considers the parameters vector α defined in 226 the parameter space, E = R 16 , since here α comprises all IC and system parameters 227 from (1), excepting N (entire population size), which is kept fixed in its nominal 228 value. For the purpose of comparison between observations and predictions, a discrete 229 set with M time-instants is considered, so that scalar observations and predictions 230 are respectively aggregated into y = (y 1 , y 2 , ..., y M ) and ψ(α) = (ψ 1 , ψ 2 , ..., ψ M ), 231 both defined in the data space F = R M . Note that the forward map ψ : E → F 232 associates to each parameters vector α an observable vector ψ(α) where the component 233 represents the number of new cases in each day of the year, i.e., ψ w = N w . In 234 practice, the parameters vector is restricted to be on the convex set of admissible 235 values, C = {α ∈ E | lb ≤ α ≤ ub} in which lb and ub are lower and upper vector 236 bounds for α, respectively.

FIGREF13.text: 239 being much more complicated to crack in comparison with the forward problem Richard 240 et al., (2012); Yaman et al., (2013). 241 The inverse problem attempts to estimate a finite number of parameters on a finite 242 dimension space, being defined in terms of a typical nonlinear misfit function. There-243 fore, Theorem 4.5.1 of Chavent, (2010) can be invoked to guarantee a proper sense of 244 well-posedness (existence, uniqueness, unimodality and local stability) for the inverse 245 problem. 246 The Trust-Region-Reflective method (TRR) is employed here to numerically ap-247 proximate a solution for the inverse problem. The core idea of the method is to 248 minimize a simpler function that represents the behavior of J(α) in a neighborhood 249 (trust-region) around α. The simpler function is defined as dependent on the trial 250 step s, characterizing the Trust-Region subproblem, and its computation is optimized 251 by restricting the subproblem to a two-dimensional subspace. The subspace is linear 252 spanned by a multiple of the gradient g and (in the bounded case) a vector obtained in 253 a scaled modified Newton step, used for the convergence condition D(α) −2 g(α) = 0, 254

FIGREF14.text: Hessian matrix Coleman,(1996). The quadratic approximation in (4) has well-259 behaved solutions Andrew, (2000) and if J(α + s) < J(α) then α is updated to α + s 260 and the process iterates, otherwise ∆ is decreased. In addition, a reflection step also 261 occurs if a given step intersects a bound: the reflected step is equivalent to the original 262 step except in the intersecting dimension, where it assumes the opposite value after 263 reflection.264The TRR algorithm also requires an initial guess for each parameter, identified in 265 the next section as "TRR input". The stopping criteria are the norm of the step and 266 the change in the value of the objective function, with a tolerance of 10 −9 .267 5. Numerical Experiments and Forecasting 268 In this section, we have used dynamically calibrated compartment model for real-269 time analysis and real-time prediction of COVID-19 outbreak for five different countries 270 which are Russia, Brazil, India, Bangladesh and the United Kingdom. Analysis and prediction for Russia 279 With much of Europe now easing itself out of confinement, Russia could become 280 the continent's new Covid-19 hotspot according to our analysis. FIGREF16.text: about 15.774K cases. As time progresses, the projected error goes down and 288 is limited about 10% for the cumulative cases and daily new cases according to our 289 calculated daily projected mean error. The basic reproduction number is 4.234 as 290 of May 08, which is close to the observed basic reproduction number for COVID-19, 291 estimated about 2-7 for COVID-19 Liu et al., (2020). The number of cumulative 292 infected cases is projected to reach 970K around August 30, and the estimated total 293 death cases will reach to about 35K in the end. To date, Russia's official death toll of 294 1,827 is relatively low because not all deaths of people who have contracted the virus are 295 being counted as Covid-19 deaths. Analysis and prediction for Brazil 299 The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic reached Latin America later 300 than other continents. The first case recorded in Brazil was on Feb 25, 2020. But now, 301 Brazil has the most cases and deaths in Latin America (155939 cases and 10627 deaths 302 as of May 9), and these are probably substantial underestimates. Our analysis projects 303 that Brazil is developing as one of the world's next coronavirus hotspots. The model 304 fitting and projection results for Brazil from late February to late August are shown 305 in Figure 4 and 5. We took real data from February 25 to May 08 to calibrate the 306 model parameters. As we can see the results from the proposed model fit the real data 307 very well. Based on the proposed model, we project that from Figure 5, the number of 308 daily detected symptomatic infectious cases in Brazil seem reaching the peak around 309 June 11 with about 26.449K cases. The basic reproduction number is estimated about 310 5.3467 as of May 11, which is in between the observed basic reproduction number 311 for COVID-19, estimated about 2-7 for COVID-19 Liu et al., (2020). This crucial 312 epidemiological parameter could blow up because of scant diagnostics and impermanent 313

FIGREF22.text: Some people might think about the possibilities of the presence of a less virulent 323 strain of the virus in India, along with the possibility that its hot weather could di-324 minish the contagion. Nevertheless, our mathematical analysis suggests that India 325 could become the new Covid-19 hotspot in South Asia. According to our projection, 326 India could continue seeing spikes in the number of cases as it time progresses de-327 spite of following lockdown and other disease mitigation measures. The first case of 328 the COVID-19 pandemic in India was reported on 30 January 2020, originating from 329 China. But now, India has the most cases and deaths in South Asia (62,808 cases 330 and 2,101 deaths as of May 9), and these are probably substantial underestimates. and 7 illustrate COVID-19 disease modeling and prediction for India from 332 late January to late August. We took real-time data from January 30 to May 8 to 333 calibrate the model parameters. As we can see, our proposed model match well for 334 the historical real data. Based on our prediction from Figure 7, the number of daily 335 detected symptomatic infectious cases in India seem reaching the peak around June 15 336 with about 9.504K cases. The basic reproduction number is 5.218 as of May 11, which 337 lies between the studied observations Liu et al., (2020). This estimation may be con-338 sidered as an overestimation of this critical parameter. Notwithstanding, this is owing 339 to the infectiousness factor of the asymptomatic spreaders. The asymptomatic and 340 minimally or moderately symptomatic should be quarantined to avoid the spread of 341 the virus, with the severely symptomatic managed and isolated in health care settings. 342 Contract tracing could be carried out to find those at risk of being in the incubation pe-343 riod by virtue of their exposure. The number of cumulative infected cases is projected 344 to reach 730K around August 30 if current pattern is held, and the estimated total 345 death cases will reach to about 43.8K in the end. The upper and lower bounds used 346 for the parameters were set compatible with the literature suggested intervals and are 347 presented in

FIGREF23.text: calibrated response(a) The number of daily detected symptomatic infectious cases measured and fitted from early March to early May, Fitting performance of calibrated SEI D I U QHRD model for India from 8 March to early May, 2020

FIGREF24.text: number of daily detected symptomatic infectious cases measured and projected for India from late January to late August, 2020 (b) The number of cumulative detected symptomatic infectious cases measured and projected for India from early March to late August, Predictions of the proposed SEI D I U QHRD model for India from late January to late August, 20205.4. Analysis and prediction for the United Kingdom352 Our analysis indicates that the United Kingdom could face risk of a second wave of 353 coronavirus infections as the United Kingsom gradually eases a nationwide lockdown. 354 According to Worldometer, (2020), by 11 May there had been 223,060 confirmed cases 355 and 32,065 deaths overall a rate of 465 deaths per million population . The outbreak 356 in London has the highest number and highest rate of infections, while England and 357 Wales are the UK countries with the highest recorded death rate per capita. The 358 prime minister of the UK is expected to unveil a coronavirus warning system when 359 he outlines his plans to gradually ease the lockdown while dropping the "stay home" 360 19 .

FIGREF25.text: TRR setup for the Figure 9 calibrated response slogan. For the UK, the modeling and projection results from January 31 to August 31 361 are shown in Figure 8 and 9. As we can see from Figure 9, the number of daily detected 362 symptomatic infectious cases reached the peak around April 10. Since then the curve 363 has been maintaining a plateau which is a really unusual scenario. This phenomenon 364 has closely been captured by our proposed model. This case study was really important 365 for the validation of our model. In fact, this elucidates the fact that this model can give 366 more precise and robust short-term predictions of COVID-19 dynamics. According to 367 our calculation, the basic reproduction number is around 4.649 as of May 09, which is 368 close to the observed basic reproduction number for COVID-19, estimated about 2-7 369 for COVID-19 Liu et al., (2020). The number cumulative infected cases is projected 370to reach 618K around August 30, and the estimated total death cases will reach to 371 about 63.48K in the above mentioned period. Importantly, as of May 11, we have 372 found in our analysis that the UK's case-fatality rate is at 17.2%, which is the worst 373 among our five studied cases. This could exacerbate as time progresses in the absence 374 of proven effective therapy or a vaccine. In addition, Our study suggests that relaxing 375 social distancing too quickly could cause thousands of additional death in the UK.

FIGREF27.text: Fitting performance of calibrated SEI D I U QHRD model for the United Kingdom from 31 January to early May, 2020 (a) The number of daily detected symptomatic infectious cases measured and projected for the United Kingdom from late January to late August, 2020 (b) The number of cumulative detected symptomatic infectious cases measured and projected for India from late January to late August, Predictions of the proposed SEI D I U QHRD model for the United Kingdom from late January to late August, 2020 21 .

FIGREF28.text: Bangladesh, the modeling and projection results from early March to late Au-381 gust of are shown in Figure 10 and Figure 11. On 22 March, Bangladesh imposed a 382 nationwide lockdown effective from 26 March to curb the spread of the novel coron-383 avirus in the wake of four deaths and at least 39 infections. Notice that, there are 384 some jumps in the number of confirmed daily new infected cases data from 16 april 385 to 20 april due to the increase of limited testing system (from 2000 samples to 2700 386 samples per day) Institute of Epidemiology, Disease Control and Research (IEDCR).

FIGREF29.text: The number of daily detected symptomatic infectious cases measured and fitted from early March to early May, 2020 (b) The number of cumulative detected symptomatic infectious cases cases measured and fitted from early March to early May, Fitting performance of calibrated SEI D I U QHRD model for Bangladesh from 8 March to early May, 2020 On 4 May, Bangladesh authorities intended to open up more factories, shopping 400 malls and logistics operations, as they could diminish the economic impact of a coron-401 avirus lockdown which they extended to May 16 Ministry of Health & Family Welfare 402 of Bangladesh, (2020). This ease of lockdown could worsen the ongoing community 403 transmission drastically. As we can see form Figure 11, the daily detected symptomatic 404 infected cases (confirmed) will reach the peak (about 2209) around June 11, 2020 and 405 then start to de-escalate. However, the probable peak time could occur in no time due 406 to easing the coronavirus lockdown too quickly and this could bring a second wave of 407 infections in the outbreak after post-peak period. The effective reproduction number is 408 around 3.5 as of May 11, which is close to the observed basic reproduction number for 409 COVID-19, estimated about 2-7 for COVID-19 Liu et al., (2020). Our estimation is 410 relatively high which due to the fact that we have considered the infectiousness factor 411 of the asymptomatic carriers. Massive level of testing is highly required to identify 412 the asymptomatic spreaders. An aggressive test-and-isolate approach could curtail the 413 burden of COVID-19, unlike other tactics like reporting contacts, wearing masks20 days. Again, we want to express that such estimation is subject to 416 differ due to various changing factors such as mitigation policies and people awareness 417 in the near term. (a) The number of daily detected symptomatic infectious cases measured and projected for Bangladesh from early March to late August, 2020 (b) The number of cumulative detected symptomatic infectious cases measured and projected for Bangladesh from early March to late August, Predictions of the proposed SEI D I U QHRD model for Bangladesh from early March to late August, 2020 418 6. Global Sensitivity Analysis 419 PRCC analysis which is a global sensitivity analysis method that calculates the 420 partial rank correlation coefficient for the model inputs (sampled by Latin hypercube 421 sampling method) and outputs Marino et al., (2008); Blower et al., (1994); Nabi et 422 al., (2020). The PRCC method assumes a monotonic relationship between the model 423 input parameters and the model outputs.

FIGREF30.text: The calculated PRCC values are between -1 and 1 and they are comparable among425 different model inputs. The sign of the PRCC values shows the qualitative relationship 426 between the model input and model output. A positive PRCC value implies that 427 when the corresponding model input increases, the model output will also increase. 428 A negative PRCC value indicates a negative correlation between the model input and 429 output. The magnitude of the PRCC sensitivity measures the significance of the model 430 input in contributing to the model output. 431 24 .

FIGREF31.text: 437quantitative relationship between the number of symptomatic infectious individuals 438 (one of the crucial model responses) and three parameters which are rate of getting 439 quarantined of susceptible individuals (q), transition rate from exposed to infectious 440 or quarantined (κ) which can also be referred as the inverse of the average incuba-441 tion period of COVID-19 and recovery rate of undetected asymptomatic (undetected) 442 infectious carriers for our proposed model. 443 In case of Russia, from Figure 12a recovery rate of undetected asymptomatic car-444 riers (φ U ) is the most negatively influential parameter when the number of detected 445 infectious individuals is our selected model response. The PRCC index is found to 446 be −0.585. In addition, rate of entering into home-quarantine or self-quarantine of 447 susceptible individuals (q) and the fraction of wrongly quarantined people who be-448 come susceptible after certain latent period (r 1 ) are the other two influential empirical 449 features with PRCC indexes are −0.5672 and 0.567 respectively. 450 In case of Brazil, rate of getting home-quarantined or self-quarantined of suscep-451 tible individuals (q), the fraction of quarantined people who become susceptible due 452 to avoiding home-quarantine (r 1 ), and the inverse of the COVID-19 mean latent pe-453 riod are the most influential parameter on the symptomatic infectious population size 454 (I D (t)). The corresponding PRCC indices are −0.62, 0.53 and −0.499. The figure 12b 455 qualitatively elucidates that a high quarantine rate of the susceptible individuals can 456 curtail the number of symptomatic infected individuals. In broader view, high efficacy 457 of home or self-quarantine and a lower unlockdown rate could flatten the I D (t) curve 458 in Brazil. 459 In case of the India, rate of getting home-quarantined or self-quarantined of sus-460 ceptible individuals (q) and the inverse of the COVID-19 incubation period are the 461 most influential parameter on the symptomatic infectious population size (I D (t)) and 462 the corresponding PRCC indexes are −0.64 and −0.62. Both the parameters are neg-463 atively sensitive to the size of detected infected individuals which is illustrated in the 464 figure 12c. This elucidates that a higher quarantine rate of the susceptible individuals 465 can reduce the number of symptomatic infected individuals. Therefore, it is obvious 466 that early unlockdown in India could worsen the outbreak situation in the blink of an 467 eye. 468 In case of the UK, rate of getting home-quarantined or self-quarantined of suscep-469 tible individuals (q) and the inverse of the COVID-19 incubation period are the most 470 influential parameter on the symptomatic infectious population size (I D (t)) and the 471 corresponding PRCC indices are −0.58 and −0.499. Both the parameters are nega-472 tively sensitive to the size of detected infected individuals which is illustrated in the 473 figure 12d. This elucidates that a higher quarantine rate of the susceptible individuals 474 can curtail the number of symptomatic infected individuals. Nevertheless, early easing 475 lockdown measures could bring a second wave of infection in the UK in no time. 476 25 .

FIGREF32.text: Sensitivity of the symptomatic infected cases while changing parameters in the proposed SEI D I U QRHD model as indicated by the PRCC index for five different countries 26 .

FIGREF33.text: Figure 12e elucidates that if the people in Bangladesh start breaking 480 social distancing restrictions extensively, then it would be difficult to control the disease 481 outbreak there. As of May 11, when Bangladesh is seeing continuous spikes in COVID-482 19 infections every day, the government has announced an easing of movement for all 483 on a limited scale with a view to reviving the country's economy. Moreover, the length 484 of the inverse of the latent period is the another negatively sensitive parameter with 485 PRCC index lying at −0proposed a methodology for the estimation of the key epidemiological 488 parameters as well as forecasting of the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic in Russia, 489 Brazil, India, Bangladesh and the UK while considering publicly available data from 490 early January 2020 to early May 2020 with the introduction of an real-time differential 491 SEI D I U QHRD epidemic model which can give more accurate and robust short-term 492 predictions. Nominal quantities for the parameters are selected from the related liter-493 ature concerning the COVID-19 infection. The calibration process is done through the 494 solution of an inverse problem with the aid of a Trust-Region-Reflective method, used 495 to pick the best parameter values that would fit the model response for the number of 496 new infectious cases per week into the disease's empirical data. Results within realistic 497 values for the parameters are presented, stating reasonable descriptions with the curve 498 shape similar to the outbreak.
